description: a(n) is the least odd number of the form p + k^2 with p prime and k > 0 which can be represented in exactly n different ways.
comments: Note that A002471 allows for k to equal zero.
references: David Wells, "The Penguin Dictionary of Curious and Interesting Numbers," Revised Edition, Penguin Books, London, 1997, page 63.
links: Donovan Johnson, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1000
example: a(3) = 27 because 27 = 23+2^2 = 11+4^2 = 2+5^2 and is the least odd number to exhibit this property of 3 representations.
author: _Robert G. Wilson v_, Mar 15 2001
